My name is Boris Vallee.

I am a finance professor
at Harvard Business School.

My research has been focusing
on financial innovation.

Within the finance segment,
the classic tension

is between voice or exit,
whether capital provider should

voice their preference and
engage with specific firms

or whether they should exit
and divest from these firms.

What we've been observing is
that banks are increasingly

internalizing nonfinancial
preferences in their strategy.

The bank coal
divestment policies
are an example of that.

We look at the coal
industry because it

is the most carbon
intensive, any substitution

away from coal into
another source of energy

should be beneficial in terms
of addressing climate change.

A much broadly
encompassing ban would

be more along the line of
first banning the financing

to any new projects that are
coal related, with the idea

that these projects are the
ones that are increasing
the footprint of that industry.

So oil and gas is another
major source of CO2 emissions.

And the way we think
about our results

is that they should carry
to that industry as well.

When speaking to advocates
for the divestment policies,

I would have two
main recommendations.

The first one is on the
strength of the bans.

So in our analysis, we observe
that the stronger the ban,

the larger the reduction in
financing, the more likely
is an asset to be retired early.

And second, there is
the extensive margin

of bans which is
aiming to broaden

the scope of the phenomenon,
having more banks join in.
My message is simple--
is that the data says it works.
